items.value: Hey! Come in!
... Hello? ... Sorry-
We're still getting the kinks worked out of this new suit.
Let me know if this is working-
I'm booting up the augmented reality overlay in your helmet now...
Ok. Can you look up at the gaze point for me?
Great! Now look at the one at your feet.
Alright! Everything seems to be in order.
Welcome to IceCube!
I'm glad you could make it all the way
down to Antarctica for this mission.
Before we send you off,
let's brief you on why you're here:

The IceCube Research Facility
 detects neutrino particles
sent from deep in space.
I'll show you the sensors in your helmet overlay.
See that grid below the facility?
Each dot is a sensor that detects light
from a passing neutrino particle.
Look! It's just detected one now!
This is great timing-
we'll use the sensor data
to pinpoint where the neutrino came from in outer space...
annnnnd... done!
Now your job is to follow this trajectory
out into space and to find the source
You're going to use your suit's Impossible Drive
and the path of the neutrino.
All you have do to is
look at the gaze point at the end of the path... Try it now.
Hello? ...
You still there?
Did you make it in one piece?
Take a second to look around and find your bearings-
it's probably pretty cool to be
further out in space than any other human has ever been!
Now you have a job to do.
Follow the path of the neutrino
that was detected by IceCube
to discover the source.
While we're waiting for the Impossible Drive to recharge,
let's go over some of the other features of your suit.
If you look at your feet,
you can use the gaze points to
switch out your helmet's view.
Go ahead-
look at your feet and switch to x-ray view.
Pretty great, right?
Look around- check out the galaxy!
This is what the universe looks like when we see with x-rays.
Your helmet is detecting x-rays
in the same way your eye would normally detect light.
Can you look at Pluto for a second?
See how it's just a big black ball?
That's because x-rays don't pass through it.
Now, let's switch to neutrino vision.
Alright- now look back to Pluto:
where'd it go?!
Pluto seems to have disappeared!
Your helmet is now only sensing neutrino particles.
Neutrinos pass through just about everything,
Even whole planets!
It's like Pluto doesn't even exist to them!
When you're ready,

Look to the gaze point at the end of the neutrino path
 and you'll follow the particle that was detected by IceCube.
We're getting some... pretty intense readings.
You're... really far out in space.
Ok- time to brief you with the details of your mission.
As you've seen, we've given your suit the ability
to see in three different ways:
Visible light, x-ray vision, and neutrino detection.
The first two have been used for decades to look out into space.
But if we want to see really far,
Neutrinos are the only thing that will work.
That's why we need the IceCube observatory.
The arrays of sensors in Antarctica
allow us to detect neutrinos from deep space.
That helps us map out parts of the universe
invisible to other telescopes.
The question you have to answer is:
What sent the neutrino that
IceCube detected back at Earth?
When you find the source at the end of your journey,
you'll need to collect data from it
using each of the three methods we've given you.
You'll use your visible light,
x-ray, and neutrino view to collect these readings.
Ok. Things might get dicey going forward.
Good luck.
Hello?
Do you read me?
You've discovered a black hole!
You need to scan it with each
of your vision modules quickly!
Then get OUT of there!
Make sure you've selected visibile light vision-
look at the black hole and collect visible light readings!
Look up at the black hole, and collect the x-ray readings!
Look back at the black hole, and collect the neutrino readings!
You did it! We have the data!
Now follow the neutrino path back to Earth! HURRY!
Wow! You did it!
I... can't believe you're alive!
....I mean, umm.. congratulations, agent!
It looks like the source
of the neutrino particle we detected with IceCube
was a black hole!
Black holes are one of the strangest,
most extreme objects in the whole universe!
Did you know that black holes can have the mass
of several million suns?
One spoonful of black hole could weigh as much
as a whole planet!
They also emit high energy neutrinos
that travel millions of lightyears back to Earth.
It would have gone totally unnoticed
if it weren't for the scientists at IceCube.
Black holes are very hard to detect-
well- because they're black!
It's impossible to see something black on a black background of space!
Fortunately, IceCube has found a way to observe them using neutrinos!
Well, that's mission complete on our end.
Until next time!
PLUTO
EARTH
MILKY WAY
VISIBLE
X-RAY
NEUTRINO
BLACK HOLE
SUN
Solar System
Local Group
ALERT
Ice
Voyager
Nothing
Extreme

Earth
START
LANGUAGE
Exploring the Universe from Antarctica
Supported by the National Science Foundation Office of Polar Programs
Award #1612504: Exploring the Universe from Antarctica

in collaboration with
